description: From Middle English locuste, locust, from Anglo-Norman locuste, Middle French locuste, and their source, Latin locusta (“locust, crustacean, lobster”). Doublet of langouste. The sense in "Mainlander" is a calque of Cantonese 蝗蟲／蝗虫 (wong4 cung4), also meaning "locust".

entries.meaning: Any of the grasshoppers, often polyphenic and usually swarming, in the family Acrididae that are very destructive to crops and other vegetation, (especially) the migratory locust (Locusta migratoria). [from 14th c.]
(now historical) A fruit or pod of the carob tree. [from 16th c.]
examples: Among other articles, they brought with them a great quantity of locusts, which are a kind of pulse, sweet and pleasant to the palate, and in shape resembling French beans, but longer.

entries.meaning: Any of various often leguminous trees and shrubs, especially of the genera Robinia and Gleditsia; the locust tree. [from 17th c.]

verbs.description: locust (third-person singular simple present locusts, present participle locusting, simple past and past participle locusted)

examples: This Philip and the black-faced swarms of Spain,The hardest, cruellest people in the world,Come locusting upon us, eat us up,Confiscate lands, goods, money  […]
